{0} is a debugger with a GUI for the Mic-1 processor invented by Andrew S. Tannenbaum, Structured Computer Organization, Fourth Edition (Prentice-Hall, 1998). You can debug the assembler code and the micro assembler code, too.

This debugger has been developed for a seminar paper.

Please see: http://git.io/croesch-md-gui
Please choose the binary files you want to debug
Wrong format of micro assembler file, did you assemble it?
Wrong format of macro assembler file, did you assemble it?

The parts of the main frame

The main frame consists of different parts:
  • First of all there is the disassembled code in the center. You can see the macro and the micro code with line numbers. The line numbers in micro code are ongoing whereas the line numbers in the macro code represent the address of the command in the memory.
  • On the upper left there are the registers, you can change the number format of their values by selecting a different radio button. By clicking the checkbox in a line of the register you set a breakpoint for that register without a value.
  • Under the view of registers you see the content of the memory. Each word in memory has its own line. As in the register view you can select the number format for representing the word values of the memory. You see the whole memory, so you can also see the binary bits of the macro code or the stack for instance.
  • At the bottom right there is a text area which contains output that would have gone to the command line and hasn't yet been put into a GUI component. So this component might be removed in future.
  • Left of that there is a text field. If its background is painted in a special color, the Mic1 is requesting input. You should enter the input for the processor and press ENTER. The text area above contains the output of the processor - of your program.

Issue-Tracking-System

I tried my best, but unfortunately there still might be some bugs and problems with using this program. If you are facing any issue with using it, don't hesitate to let me know! You also might have a brilliant idea what the program should be able to handle. If so, let me know!
Just visit https://github.com/croesch/micro-debug-gui/issues and create an issue.

Development

If you would like to contribute to this program I'm looking forward to hearing from you! You can write me a mail or fork the project directly from github: https://github.com/croesch/micro-debug-gui/ I would be pleased if you let me know if you start working on the project.
